blok_andere_gegevens.message: Data that could give insight in the spread of the virus.

laatst_bijgewerkt.message: The dashboard last received new data on {{dateOfInsertion}}.
laatst_bijgewerkt.title: Last updated

notificatie.titel: New COVID-19 variant overshadows more positive developments
notificatie.bericht:
A moderately positive overview can be observed in the week of 13 to 19 January, as an effect of the lockdown that started on 15 December. In that week, the reported number of people who tested positive for COVID-19 decreased by 21.5% compared to the week before, dropping to 38.776 newly reported COVID-19 infections. This overview is overshadowed by the rising number of cases involving the SARS-CoV-2 variant that resulted in a massive influx of patients in hospitals in the United Kingdom and Ireland. It is estimated that in the Netherlands about 10% of the people who became infected last week have the more contagious UK variant. That is twice as many compared to the week before that. 
We are facing two variants of the virus that seem to be spreading in the Netherlands at different speeds. As a result, there are essentially two separate COVID-19 epidemics: one epidemic involving the ‘old’ variant, in which infections are decreasing, and another epidemic involving the UK variant, in which infections are increasing.

link.text: View the full message from the RIVM

header.title: Coronavirus dashboard
header.text: The coronavirus dashboard provides information on the development of the coronavirus in the Netherlands.

ic_opnames_per_dag.datums: Calculated: {{dateOfReport}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
ic_opnames_per_dag.pagina_toelichting: Number of confirmed COVID-19 cases who are admitted to a hospital intensive care unit (ICU) per day.
ic_opnames_per_dag.barscale_screenreader_text: {{value}} intensive care-admissions by day. Alert value: {{signaalwaarde}} admissions per day.
ic_opnames_per_dag.extra_uitleg:
Number of confirmed COVID-19 cases who are admitted to a hospital intensive care unit (ICU) per day. This figure is an average for the daily admissions over the past three days.

Note: Although hospitals try to register COVID-19 patients promptly, it is likely that the numbers of the last days are yet incomplete.

kpi_bedbezetting.title: ICU beds occupied by COVID-19 patients
kpi_bedbezetting.description: This number shows how many ICU beds are occupied by COVID-19 patients. The percentage shows what proportion of all occupied ICU beds this is. This is unrelated to maximum ICU capacity.

chart_bedbezetting.title: ICU bed occupancy over time
chart_bedbezetting.description: This graph shows the progression of the number of ICU beds occupied by COVID-19 patients.

ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.datums: Calculated: {{dateOfReport}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.pagina_toelichting: A rise in the number of patients with COVID-19 could overburden hospitals. This section of the dashboard shows the number regular hospital beds occupied by patients with COVID-19 and the number of patients with COVID-19 admitted to hospital each day. The dashboard provides national and regional figures drawn from various sources. Please note: as of 14 January 2021 the dashboard shows the number of hospital admissions reported daily. We no longer show a three-day average.
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.extra_uitleg: Number of people with COVID-19 admitted to hospital daily (excluding ICU admissions). This figure shows how many hospital admissions are reported per day. It may include hospital admissions that occurred in previous days because reporting delays are common.
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.map_titel: Residence of patients admitted to hospital
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.map_toelichting: This map shows, by municipality or safety region, where people live who have been admitted to hospital (non-ICU admissions) with COVID-19. Please note that people may have been admitted to hospital somewhere else in the Netherlands; the map therefore does not show admission numbers per hospital. The figures here reflect the daily hospital admissions reported to the National Intensive Care Evaluation Registry (Stichting NICE). Tergooi hospitals, Amstelland Hospital and Flevoziekenhuis do not currently share their COVID-19 hospital admission data with Stichting NICE. As a result, the actual figures in some municipalities and safety regions are higher than they appear on the map.
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.linechart_titel: Progression in hospital admissions over time
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.barscale_screenreader_text: {{value}} hospital admissions per day. Alert value: {{signaalwaarde}} admissions per day.

kpi_bedbezetting.title: Hospital beds occupied by COVID-19 patients
kpi_bedbezetting.description: This number shows how many non-ICU hospital beds are occupied by COVID-19 patients.

chart_bedbezetting.title: Hospital bed occupancy over time
chart_bedbezetting.description: This graph shows the progression of the number of non-ICU hospital beds occupied by COVID-19 patients.

ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.linechart_description: This graph shows hospital admissions. The figure for each day indicates the number of people actually admitted on that day, not the number of admissions reported on that day. This gives a clear picture of the development of coronavirus in the Netherlands. There are often reporting delays of a few days for hospital admissions; data for the most recent days is therefore incomplete.

positief_geteste_personen.barscale_toelichting: This figure shows how many people per 100,000 inhabitants were reported yesterday as testing positive for COVID-19 (number of confirmed cases).
positief_geteste_personen.kpi_toelichting: This number shows how many confirmed cases were reported yesterday. Part of this number are positive tests of previous days, that have been reported later.
positief_geteste_personen.map_titel: Distribution of confirmed cases in the Netherlands
positief_geteste_personen.map_toelichting: These maps show how many confirmed cases of COVID-19 were reported yesterday per 100,000 inhabitants.
positief_geteste_personen.linechart_toelichting: This graph shows how many confirmed cases of COVID-19 were reported in the selected period per 100,000 inhabitants.
positief_geteste_personen.barchart_toelichting: This figure shows the distribution of confirmed cases by age group. This is based on only the new cases that have been reported in comparison to the day before.

besmettelijke_personen.title: Number of infectious people
besmettelijke_personen.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
besmettelijke_personen.legenda_line: The number of infectious people in the Netherlands.
besmettelijke_personen.legenda_marge: The confidence interval shows the range between which the number of infectious people falls.
besmettelijke_personen.geen_signaalwaarde_beschikbaar: Due to a technical problem the data is currently not showing as intended. This is being investigated.
besmettelijke_personen.toelichting_pagina: A person who carries coronavirus can infect other people within a certain time frame. How long someone is infectious for differs from one person to another. The number of infectious people is estimated using data from various sources. It is not possible to know exactly how many people are infectious, but we can indicate whether there are dozens, hundreds, thousands or even more.
besmettelijke_personen.barscale_titel: Average number of infectious people per 100.000 inhabitants.
besmettelijke_personen.cijfer_titel: Estimated number of infectious people in the Netherlands:
besmettelijke_personen.cijfer_toelichting: A calculation of how many people with COVID-19 can transmit the virus. This number is calculated by the RIVM.

metadata.title: Number of infectious people | Dashboard Coronavirus | Government.nl
metadata.description: National overview of how many people with COVID-19 can transmit the virus. This number is calculated by the RIVM.

besmettelijke_personen.barscale_toelichting: A calculation of how many people with COVID-19 per 100.000 people can transmit the virus. This number is calculated by the RIVM.

reference.text: Read more in 'explanation of the data presented'.

reproductiegetal.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
reproductiegetal.legenda_r: The reproduction number is not an exact value but a reliable estimate. Reproduction numbers (R) using data from less than two weeks ago are not reliable, therefore, the line depicting R stops at a date two weeks in the past.
reproductiegetal.legenda_marge: The confidence interval shows the range between which the number R falls. This is updated on a weekly basis.
reproductiegetal.reproductie_explainer_alt: Image to support the explanation above
reproductiegetal.pagina_toelichting: The reproduction number shows how fast the virus is spreading. The number shows how many people are on average infected by one patient with COVID-19.
reproductiegetal.barscale_toelichting: Number of people infected by one infectious person.
reproductiegetal.extra_uitleg: The reproduction number shows how fast the virus is spreading. This number shows how many people are on average infected by one patient with COVID-19. The number of transmissions remains more or less constant when the reproduction number is 1, declines when it is less than 1 and increases when the number is above 1.

metadata.title: Reproduction number | Dashboard Coronavirus | Government.nl
metadata.description: The reproduction number shows how fast the virus is spreading. This number shows how many people are on average infected by one patient with COVID-19.

reference.text: Read more in 'explanation of the data presented'.

overige_gegevens.title: To be developed
overige_gegevens.text: We aim to expand the dashboard in the future with the following data:

list.content:
The RIVM monitors the spread of infectious diseases in many ways. This is also the case for COVID-19. One of these ways is to look at persons exhibiting symptoms that could indicate an infection. The RIVM does this with the Infectieradar.

Everyone in the Netherlands can take part in the Infectieradar. Participants self-report once a week if they have (had) a fever or other symptoms. Even if participants don't have any symptoms they pass this on to us. This way, signals of an increase or decrease in the spread of the virus are picked up earlier.

list.text: Contact tracing by the municipal public health service (GGD)
list.content: When someone is infected with COVID-19, the municipal health service (GGD) tries to find out where they got it from and who they recently had contact with. The purpose is to discover whether the virus has also been transmitted to any other people.

Care professionals with COVID-19 can infect their patients, so monitoring care professionals’ health can help contain the spread of the disease. This means keeping track of the number of care professionals who are infected with coronavirus and the number who report ill. This data also helps the healthcare system cope with increases in workload.
Data on the movement of people can indicate how the coronavirus is spreading. The aim is to show this per municipality.
The compliance monitor provides insight into the degree to which people are able to follow the coronavirus measures.

RIVM routinely collects data from behavioural studies that shed light on trends in compliance with and support for the basic rules that apply, like washing hands, staying home and getting tested if you have symptoms.

verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.titel: Nursing homes – Number of infected locations
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.pagina_toelichting:
This number is an estimation of the number of new nursing home locations where there is at least one confirmed case.

The calculation method has been changed on the 29th of September. Please also see the data explanation section.
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.barscale_titel: Number of new locations per day
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.barscale_toelichting: Number of new locations where there is at least one confirmed case. A nursing home is counted as a 'new location; when there have not been any confirmed cases for at least 28 days, which is twice the incubation period.
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.kpi_toelichting: This figure is an estimate of the number of nursing homes where in the past 28 days at least one (new) COVID-19 infection (confirmed by a positive test) is reported. The percentage shows what proportion of the total number of nursing homes in the Netherlands this is.
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.linechart_titel: Progression over time in the total number of infected locations
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.barscale_screenreader_text: {{value}} new locations where there is at least one confirmed case, per day.
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.map_toelichting: This maps shows the percentage of nursing homes where in the past 28 days at least one (new) COVID-19 infection (confirmed by a positive test) is reported.

The calculation method has been changed on the 29th of September. Please also see the data explanation section.

rioolwater_metingen.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
rioolwater_metingen.pagina_toelichting: Average number of coronavirus particles per 100.000 inhabitants found in wastewater. The weekly average is calculated by adding up all the values measured at roughly 300 locations and dividing this by the number of measurements taken.If someone is infected with coronavirus, coronavirus particles will usually be present in their excrement, which is carried away into the sewers. By testing wastewater samples collected at treatment plants, we can find out how much of the virus is present in a given area. Such testing is still experimental. In the long run we hope that wastewater testing will enable early detection and monitoring of coronavirus.
rioolwater_metingen.barscale_titel: Average number of virus particles per 100.000 inhabitants
rioolwater_metingen.extra_uitleg: The weekly average for all of the Netherlands is calculated by adding up all the values measured in one week and dividing this by the number of measurements taken.
rioolwater_metingen.linechart_titel: Average number of virus particles per 100.000 inhabitants over time

metadata.title: Sewage water examination | Dashboard Coronavirus | Government.nl
metadata.description: Average number of virus particles per 100.000 inhabitants

rioolwater_metingen.titel_kpi: Average number of coronavirus particles per 100,000 inhabitants
rioolwater_metingen.total_installation_count_description: Weekly number of sewage water treatment plants that have reported at least one measurement. The weekly average is calculated by taking the average of all measurements at these locations. This number can vary each week because not all measurements are successful.
rioolwater_metingen.map_titel: Average number of virus particles per 100.000 inhabitants
rioolwater_metingen.map_toelichting: This map shows the average number of virus particles per 100.000 inhabitants, per safety region.

reference.text: Find out more about testing wastewater for coronavirus in the explanation of data presented.

rioolwater_metingen.kpi_titel: Average number of coronavirus particles per 100.000 people

veiligheidsregio_ziekenhuisopnames_per_d.pagina_toelichting: A rise in the number of patients with COVID-19 could overburden hospitals. This section of the dashboard shows the number regular hospital beds occupied by patients with COVID-19 and the number of patients with COVID-19 admitted to hospital each day. The dashboard provides national and regional figures drawn from various sources. Please note: as of 14 January 2021 the dashboard shows the number of hospital admissions reported daily. We no longer show a three-day average.
veiligheidsregio_ziekenhuisopnames_per_d.extra_uitleg: Number of people from this safety region with COVID-19 admitted to hospital (excl. ICU) on a daily basis. This number entails the amount of hospital admissions reported on one day and can include admissions from previous days. Patients can be admitted to hospitals in other regions.
veiligheidsregio_ziekenhuisopnames_per_d.map_toelichting: This map shows, by municipality or safety region, where people live who have been admitted to hospital (non-ICU admissions) with COVID-19. Please note that people may have been admitted to hospital somewhere else in the Netherlands; the map therefore does not show admission numbers per hospital. The figures here reflect the daily hospital admissions reported to the National Intensive Care Evaluation Registry (Stichting NICE). Tergooi hospitals, Amstelland Hospital and Flevoziekenhuis do not currently share their COVID-19 hospital admission data with Stichting NICE. As a result, the actual figures in some municipalities and safety regions are higher than they appear on the map.

The figure for each day indicates the number of people actually admitted on that day, not the number of admissions reported on that day. This gives a clear picture of the development of coronavirus in the Netherlands. There are often reporting delays of a few days for hospital admissions; data for the most recent days is therefore incomplete.

This section of the dashboard shows the number regular hospital beds occupied by patients with COVID-19 and the number of patients with COVID-19 admitted to hospital each day. The dashboard provides national and regional figures drawn from various sources. Please note: as of 14 January 2021 the dashboard shows the number of hospital admissions reported daily. We no longer show a three-day average.
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.datums: Calculated: {{dateOfReport}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.extra_uitleg: Number of people from this municipality with COVID-19 admitted to hospital (excl. ICU) on a daily basis. This number entails the amount of hospital admissions reported on one day. These could include admissions from previous days. Patients can be admitted to hospitals in other regions.
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.map_titel: Distribution of hospital admissions in safety region of {{municipality}}
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.map_toelichting: This map shows, by municipality or safety region, where people live who have been admitted to hospital (non-ICU admissions) with COVID-19. Please note that people may have been admitted to hospital somewhere else in the Netherlands; the map therefore does not show admission numbers per hospital. The figures here reflect the daily hospital admissions reported to the National Intensive Care Evaluation Registry (Stichting NICE). Tergooi hospitals, Amstelland Hospital and Flevoziekenhuis do not currently share their COVID-19 hospital admission data with Stichting NICE. As a result, the actual figures in some municipalities and safety regions are higher than they appear on the map.
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.linechart_titel: Progression in hospital admissions over time
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.barscale_screenreader_text: {{value}} hospital admissions per day. Alert value: {{signaalwaarde}} admissions per day.
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.linechart_description: This graph shows hospital admissions. The figure for each day indicates the number of people actually admitted on that day, not the number of admissions reported on that day. This gives a clear picture of the development of coronavirus in the Netherlands. There are often reporting delays of a few days for hospital admissions; data for the most recent days is therefore incomplete.

metadata.title: Hospital admissions {{municipalityName}} | Dashboard Coronavirus | Government.nl
metadata.description: Overview of the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in {{municipalityName}} who are admitted to a hospital per day.

gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.titel_kpi: Number of hospital admissions reported on one day.

reference.text: Read more in 'explanation of the data presented'.

gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.kpi_titel: Number of hospital admissions reported on one day.
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.linechart_legend_underreported_titel: Data for recent days is incomplete due to reporting delays

gemeente_positief_geteste_personen.pagina_toelichting: By keeping track of the number of confirmed cases, we are able to determine the rate at which the virus is spreading before it reaches the intensive care. This keeps us prepared.
gemeente_positief_geteste_personen.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
gemeente_positief_geteste_personen.barscale_titel: Average number of confirmed cases per 100,000 inhabitants per day
gemeente_positief_geteste_personen.barscale_toelichting: This number shows how many people per 100,000 inhabitants were reported yesterday as testing positive for COVID-19 (number of confirmed cases).
gemeente_positief_geteste_personen.kpi_toelichting: This number shows how many confirmed cases were reported yesterday. Part of this number are positive tests of previous days, that have been reported later.
gemeente_positief_geteste_personen.map_titel: Distribution of confirmed cases in safety region of {{municipality}}
gemeente_positief_geteste_personen.map_toelichting: This map shows how many confirmed cases of COVID-19 were reported yesterday in this municipality and other municipalities in the same safety region, per 100,000 inhabitants.
gemeente_positief_geteste_personen.linechart_toelichting: This graph shows how many confirmed cases of COVID-19 were reported in the selected period in this municipality per 100,000 inhabitants.
gemeente_positief_geteste_personen.barchart_toelichting: This figure shows the distribution of confirmed cases by age group. This is based on only the new cases that have been reported in comparison to the day before.

metadata.title: Confirmed cases in  {{municipalityName}} | Dashboard Coronavirus | Government.nl
metadata.description: Overview of confirmed cases in municipality {{municipalityName}}

reference.text: Read more in 'explanation of the data presented'.

gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.pagina_toelichting: If someone is infected with coronavirus, coronavirus particles will usually be present in their excrement, which is carried away into the sewers. By testing wastewater samples collected at treatment plants, we can find out how much of the virus is present in a given area. Such testing is still experimental. In the long run we hope that wastewater testing will enable early detection and monitoring of coronavirus.
gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.barscale_titel: Average number of virus particles per 100,000 inhabitants
gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.extra_uitleg: The weekly average for the municipality is calculated by adding up all the values measured in one week and dividing this by the number of measurements taken.
gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.linechart_titel: Average number of virus particles per 100.000 inhabitants over time
gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.bar_chart_title: Most recent measurement per location in {{municipality}}
gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.bar_chart_axis_title: Average number of coronavirus particles per 100,000 inhabitants

metadata.title: Sewage water examination in {{municipalityName}} | Dashboard Coronavirus | Government.nl
metadata.description: Overview of sewage water examination and the number of measured COVID-19 virus particles in municipality {{municipalityName}}.

gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.nodata_sidebar: This information is not available for this municipality.
gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.total_installation_count_description: Weekly number of sewage water treatment plants that have reported at least one measurement. The weekly average is calculated by taking the average of all measurements at these locations. This number can vary each week because not all measurements are successful.

reference.text: Find out more about testing wastewater for coronavirus in the explanation of data presented.

gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.kpi_titel: Average number of coronavirus particles per 100.000 people

positief_geteste_personen_ggd.titel: Percentage of positive test results at GGD test locations
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.summary_title: {{percentage}} of the test results at GGD test locations had a positive result
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.toelichting: The figures below provide information on the overall number of tests conducted at GGD test locations and the percentage of positive results. An increase in the percentage of positive tests could be an indication that transmission of the virus is on the rise. Please note that most but not all tests are conducted by the GGD. This means that the total number of people who have tested positive differs from the number of people who have tested positive at GGD test locations.
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.totaal_getest_week_titel: Average number of tests conducted by the GGD per day
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.totaal_getest_week_uitleg: The average number of tests conducted per day, calculated over seven days. The tests of which the results are as yet unknown, are excluded from this average.
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.positief_getest_week_titel: Number of people who have tested positive
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.positief_getest_week_uitleg: Percentage of positive tests conducted at GGD test locations (for which results are known).  This figure is a seven-day average.
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.positief_getest_getest_week_uitleg: This represents {{numerator}} of {{denominator}} tests for which the result is known.
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.linechart_percentage_titel: Percentage of GGD positive test results, over time
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.linechart_percentage_toelichting: This graph shows the daily percentage of tests conducted by the GGD with positive results in relation to the total number of GGD tests conducted that day for which the results are known. The data is organised based on the date on which the tests were conducted by the GGD. On average it takes one to two days before test results are known.
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.linechart_totaltests_titel: Number of test results over time
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.linechart_totaltests_toelichting: This graph shows the daily number of tests conducted at GGD test locations for which the results are known and the number of known results that are positive, over time. The data is organised based on the date on which the tests were conducted by the GGD. On average it takes one to two days before test results are known.
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.linechart_totaltests_legend_label: GGD tests for which results are known
positief_geteste_personen_ggd.linechart_positivetests_legend_label: GGD tests with a positive result

reference.text: Read more in 'explanation of the data presented'.

veiligheidsregio_verpleeghuis_besmette_l.pagina_toelichting:
This number is an estimation of the number of new nursing home locations where there is at least one confirmed case.

The calculation method has been changed on the 29th of September. Please also see the data explanation section.
veiligheidsregio_verpleeghuis_besmette_l.barscale_titel: Number of new locations per day
veiligheidsregio_verpleeghuis_besmette_l.barscale_toelichting: Number of new locations where there is at least one confirmed case. A nursing home is counted as a 'new location; when there have not been any confirmed cases for at least 28 days, which is twice the incubation period.
veiligheidsregio_verpleeghuis_besmette_l.kpi_toelichting: This figure is an estimate of the number of nursing homes where in the past 28 days at least one (new) COVID-19 infection (confirmed by a positive test) is reported. The percentage shows what proportion of the total number of nursing homes in this safety region this is.
veiligheidsregio_verpleeghuis_besmette_l.linechart_titel: Progression over time in the total number of infected locations
veiligheidsregio_verpleeghuis_besmette_l.barscale_screenreader_text: {{value}} new locations where there is at least one confirmed case, per day.

metadata.title: Compliance and support | Coronavirus dashboard | Government.nl
metadata.description: National overview of compliance and support

pagina.toelichting: The Netherlands’ approach is essentially to control the virus as much as possible, avoid overburdening the healthcare system and protect vulnerable groups. We can get coronavirus under control, but only if we all follow the basic rules.

nl_gedrag.datums: This survey was carried out between {{weekStart}} and {{weekEnd}}. Is updated every 3 weeks.

onderzoek_uitleg.toelichting: Every three weeks a survey of a representative sample of the Dutch population is carried out. Survey respondents all answer the same questions about the basic rules that the government has laid down to combat coronavirus. The purpose of the survey is to find out to what extent the public supports and follows these rules. The survey is coordinated and published by RIVM, and carried out by Kantar Public.

verdeling_in_nederland.intro: Select a basic rule to see the differences between safety regions.

voetnoot.compliance: This table shows the percentage of survey respondents who reported following each of the basic rules in their daily life.
voetnoot.support: This table shows the percentage of survey respondents who reported supporting each of the basic rules.

voetnoot_asterisk.compliance: * Any difference compared to the previous measurement can be shown with 95% certainty.
voetnoot_asterisk.support: * Any difference compared to the previous measurement can be shown with 95% certainty.

intro.compliance: This graph shows the changes in the percentage of respondents who reported following the basic rule in their daily life.
intro.support: This graph shows the changes in the percentage of respondents who reported supporting the basic rule.

reference.text: Read more in 'explanation of the data presented'.

metadata.title: Compliance and support | Coronavirus dashboard | Government.nl
metadata.description: National overview of compliance and support

pagina.toelichting: The Netherlands’ approach is essentially to control the virus as much as possible, avoid overburdening the healthcare system and protect vulnerable groups. We can get coronavirus under control, but only if we all follow the basic rules.

regionaal_gedrag.datums: This survey was carried out between {{weekStart}} and {{weekEnd}}. Is updated every 3 weeks.

onderzoek_uitleg.toelichting: Every three weeks a survey of a representative sample of the Dutch population is carried out. Survey respondents all answer the same questions about the basic rules that the government has laid down to combat coronavirus. The purpose of the survey is to find out to what extent the public supports and follows these rules. The survey is coordinated and published by RIVM, and carried out by Kantar Public.

voetnoot.support: This table shows the percentage of survey respondents who reported supporting each of the basic rules.

voetnoot_asterisk.support: * Any difference compared to the previous measurement can be shown with 95% certainty.

intro.compliance: This graph shows the changes in the percentage of respondents who reported following the basic rule in their daily life.
intro.support: This graph shows the changes in the percentage of respondents who reported supporting the basic rule.

infected_age_groups.title: Distribution by age
infected_age_groups.description: The blue (right) bars in this graph show which age group positive tested persons belong to. The gray (left) bars show how large each age group is in relation to the entire Dutch population. The blue and gray bars together show whether age groups have relatively more or less positive tested persons. For example: 10% of all positive tested persons are in their thirties (blue bar) and 14% of all Dutch people are in their thirties (gray bar). In this example, the age group thirties has relatively fewer positive tested people. The chart is updated daily and covers only the most recently reported cases.
infected_age_groups.example: For example: of all positive tested people is {{infectedPercentage}} between {{ageGroupRange}} years old. Of all Dutch people is {{ageGroupPercentage}} between {{ageGroupRange}} years old.

graph.age_group_percentage_title: Distribution of age groups in the Netherlands
graph.age_group_percentage_tooltip: of the population is {{ageGroupRange}} years old.
graph.infected_percentage_tooltip: of the total amount of positive tested persons is {{ageGroupRange}} years old.
graph.accessibility_description: Graph with percentages for the distribution of the population and the distribution of positive tested age groups.

gehandicaptenzorg_besmette_locaties.datums: Latest values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
gehandicaptenzorg_besmette_locaties.titel: Disability care homes - no. of infected locations
gehandicaptenzorg_besmette_locaties.pagina_toelichting: This is an estimate of the number of disability care homes that currently have at least one confirmed COVID-19 case.
gehandicaptenzorg_besmette_locaties.barscale_titel: Number of new locations per day
gehandicaptenzorg_besmette_locaties.barscale_toelichting: This figure shows the number of disability care homes where at least one resident was reported as testing positive for COVID-19 yesterday. A disability care home is considered to have a new outbreak if there had been no new cases of COVID-19 in the home in the previous 28 days (i.e. twice the length of the incubation period).
gehandicaptenzorg_besmette_locaties.kpi_titel: Total no. of new infected locations
gehandicaptenzorg_besmette_locaties.kpi_toelichting: This figure shows the total number of disability care homes that have reported at least one confirmed COVID-19 case among residents, based on a positive test, in the last 28 days. The percentage expresses the share of all disability care homes in the Netherlands with confirmed COVID-19 cases.
gehandicaptenzorg_besmette_locaties.linechart_titel: Total no. of infected locations – progression over time
gehandicaptenzorg_besmette_locaties.map_titel: Distribution of infected locations in the Netherlands
gehandicaptenzorg_besmette_locaties.map_toelichting: This map shows the number of disability care homes that have reported at least one confirmed COVID-19 case, based on a positive test, in the last 28 days.

gehandicaptenzorg_positief_geteste_perso.pagina_toelichting: People who live in disability care homes are often extra vulnerable to coronavirus infection. Because of this, Municipal health services (GGDs) monitor whether a persons who tests positive for COVID-19 lives in a disability care home. By doing so, measures can be taken if the number of cases in residential care increases.

gehandicaptenzorg_positief_geteste_perso.map_toelichting: These maps show how many people per 100,000 inhabitants were reported yesterday as testing positive for COVID-19 (number of confirmed cases).

veiligheidsregio_gehandicaptenzorg_posit.pagina_toelichting: People who live in disability care homes are often extra vulnerable to coronavirus infection. Because of this, Municipal health services (GGDs) monitor whether a persons who tests positive for COVID-19 lives in a disability care home. By doing so, measures can be taken if the number of cases in residential care increases.
veiligheidsregio_gehandicaptenzorg_posit.map_toelichting: These maps show how many people per 100,000 inhabitants were reported yesterday as testing positive for COVID-19 (number of confirmed cases).

section_positive_tested.description: People aged over 70 are extra vulnerable to coronavirus infection. Keeping track of the number of infections among over-70s who are still living independently in their own homes makes targeted measures possible.

section_deceased_rivm.title: Deaths
section_deceased_rivm.description: These figures show the number of deaths related directly or indirectly to COVID-19, as reported to the GGD. The actual number of deaths related to COVID-19 may be higher because not all people with COVID-19 get tested and there is no requirement for reporting COVID-19 related deaths.

section_sterftemonitor.title: Mortality monitor
section_sterftemonitor.description: Every week the national office Statistics Netherlands (CBS) publishes data on the total number of deaths in the Netherlands and compares this to the predicted number of deaths, corrected for extreme temperatures, epidemics, etc. If more deaths occur than predicted, these are considered excess deaths. This graph may show a more complete picture of COVID-19 related deaths than the numbers reported by the GGD because not everyone who dies from COVID-19 has been tested for it.
section_sterftemonitor.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.

cbs.download: https://opendata.cbs.nl/ODataApi/odata/70895ned/TypedDataSet?$filter=((Geslacht eq '1100')) and ((LeeftijdOp31December eq '10000')) and (substringof('W', Perioden) eq true)&$select=Perioden, Overledenen_1

reference.text: Read more in 'explanation of the data presented'

cbs_message.title: Mortality slightly down in week 2, remains high
cbs_message.message: Estimated mortality in week 2 of 2021 (11 to 17 January inclusive) stands at 3,850. This is 500 deaths in excess of the expected number for this period. The number of deaths in week 1 stood at 4,099. Statistics Netherlands (CBS) reports this based on the latest provisional weekly mortality figures. As of week 39 of 2020, weekly mortality has been higher than expected. During the current second epidemic wave, slightly over 60 thousand people have died up to the second week of 2021 inclusive. This is nearly 9 thousand more deaths than would normally be expected in this period.

section_sterftemonitor.deceased_monitor_chart_title: Total number of deaths per week
section_sterftemonitor.deceased_monitor_chart_description: This graph shows the total number of deaths per week in the Netherlands in 2020. The actual number of deaths is compared to the number of deaths predicted based on the figures from preceding years. The light blue line, drawn within its range of uncertainty, shows the number of deaths predicted over the year. The dark blue line shows the number of actual deaths.

deceased_age_groups.title: COVID-19 deaths by age
deceased_age_groups.description: The blue bars on the right of this graph show the age distribution of people who have died from COVID 19. The grey bars on the left show how large each age group is in relation to the entire Dutch population. Taken together, the blue and grey bars show whether there are proportionately more or fewer COVID-19 deaths in each age group. If, for example, the graph shows that people in their sixties represent 12% of the Dutch population (grey bar) and that this same group represents 10% of the people in the Netherlands who have died from COVID-19 (blue bar), that means there are proportionately fewer deaths from COVID-19 among people in their sixties. The graph is updated daily and includes all deaths since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. Please note that RIVM groups COVID-19 deaths among people younger than 50 together; the low numbers could otherwise be traceable back to individual people.
